xxl.cursors
Class BufferedCursor

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.BufferedCursor
Direct Known Subclasses:
NestedLoops, SortMerge
public class BufferedCursor
extends Object
implements Cursor

A BufferedCursor implements the peek-functionality.
A Cursor that does not support the peek-operation can be wrapped by an object of this class.

Note: Every Iterator given to a constructor of this class will implicitely be wrapped to a Cursor that supports the peek-method.

Example usage:

(1) Implementatin to guarantee that a given Cursor supports the peek- functionality. 


 		BufferedCursor bufferedCursor = cursor.supportsPeek()? cursor: new BufferedCursor(cursor);

(2) Implementation to guarantee that a given PeekIterator supports the peek- functionality. 


 		Cursor cursor = peekIterator instanceof Cursor? (Cursor)peekIterator: new PeekIteratorCursor(peekIterator);
 		BufferedCursor bufferedCursor = cursor.supportsPeek()? cursor: new BufferedCursor(cursor);

(3) Implementation to guarantee that a given Iterator supports the peek- functionality. 


 		Cursor cursor = iterator instanceof Cursor?
 			(Cursor)iterator:
 			iterator instanceof PeekIterator?
 				(Cursor)new PeekIteratorCursor((PeekIterator)iterator):
 				(Cursor)new IteratorCursor(iterator);
 		BufferedCursor bufferedCursor = cursor.supportsPeek()? cursor: new BufferedCursor(cursor);
This kind of implementation can effectively be used with regard to constructors. For example the class WhileTaker uses this kind of implementation to guarantee the peek-functionality.

See Also:
Cursor, Iterator

Field Detail

cursor

protected Cursor cursor
The Cursor to be wrapped.

next

protected Object next
Next Object to be returned by next or peek.

isValid

protected boolean isValid
A flag that signals if the next element has already been consumed from the underlying cursor. That means if the BufferedCursor's peek-method is called and the next element is returned, this flag is set to true with the intention to return the right element when the BufferedCursor's next-method is called, namely next and not cursor.next().

hasNext

protected boolean hasNext
A flag that signals if the underlying has more elements.

Method Detail

close

public void close()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Closes the BufferedCursor by closing the underlying cursor.
Signals the BufferedCursor to cleanup resources, close files, etc. After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results.
Multiple calls to close() do not have any effect, i.e. if close() was called the BufferedCursor remains in the state "closed".
The input-Cursor is closed and the flags hasNext and isValid are set to false.
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Returns hasNext || (hasNext = cursor.hasNext()).
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the BufferedCursor has more elements.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
This element will be removed from the underlying collection, if next is called.
Tests if the flag isValid is true then it is set to false, otherwise the next element is consumed from the input-Cursor. hasNext is set to false and next is returned.
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements, i.e. the method hasNext returned false.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection.
If isValid is false cursor.next() is saved in the field next and returned, the flag isValid is also set to true.
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements, i.e. the method hasNext returned false.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this BufferedCursor. (not possible)

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the BufferedCursor. (optional operation)
This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. The behavior of a BufferedCursor is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this BufferedCursor.
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the BufferedCursor to its initial state. (optional operation)
That means the reset method of the input-Cursor is called. So the caller is able to traverse the underlying collection again. The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying collection, are still persistent.
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the input-Cursor.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true, because the peek-operation is supported by every BufferedCursor.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this BufferedCursor.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the object that was returned by the last call to next or peek. (optional operation)
This operation must not be called after a call to hasNext. It should follow a call to next or peek. This method should be called only once per call to next or peek.
The behavior of a BufferedCursor is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method. The update method of the input-Cursor is called.
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if there is no object which can be updated.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the input-Cursor.
